snp1.4:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā magadhesu viharati dakkhiṇāgirismiṃ ekanāḷāyaṃ brāhmaṇagāme.
snp1.4:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Magadhans in the Southern Hills near the brahmin village of Ekanāḷa.

snp1.4:1.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena kasibhāradvājassa brāhmaṇassa pañcamattāni naṅgalasatāni payuttāni honti vappakāle.
snp1.4:1.3.eng: Now at that time the brahmin Bhāradvāja the Farmer had harnessed around five hundred plows, it being the season for sowing.

snp1.4:1.4.pli: Atha kho bhagavā pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya yena kasibhāradvājassa brāhmaṇassa kammanto tenupasaṅkami.
snp1.4:1.4.eng: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, went to where Bhāradvāja the Farmer was working.

snp1.4:1.5.pli: Tena kho pana samayena kasibhāradvājassa brāhmaṇassa parivesanā vattati.
snp1.4:1.5.eng: Now at that time Bhāradvāja the Farmer was distributing food.

snp1.4:1.6.pli: Atha kho bhagavā yena parivesanā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi.
snp1.4:1.6.eng: Then the Buddha went to where the distribution was taking place and stood to one side.

snp1.4:2.1.pli: Addasā kho kasibhāradvājo brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ piṇḍāya ṭhitaṃ.
snp1.4:2.1.eng: Bhāradvāja the Farmer saw him standing for alms

snp1.4:2.3.pli: “ahaṃ kho, samaṇa, kasāmi ca vapāmi ca; kasitvā ca vapitvā ca bhuñjāmi.
snp1.4:2.3.eng: “I plough and sow, ascetic, and then I eat.

snp1.4:2.4.pli: Tvampi, samaṇa, kasassu ca vapassu ca; kasitvā ca vapitvā ca bhuñjassū”ti.
snp1.4:2.4.eng: You too should plough and sow, then you may eat.”

snp1.4:3.1.pli: “Ahampi kho, brāhmaṇa, kasāmi ca vapāmi ca; kasitvā ca vapitvā ca bhuñjāmī”ti.
snp1.4:3.1.eng: “I too plough and sow, brahmin, and then I eat.”

snp1.4:3.2.pli: “Na kho pana mayaṃ passāma bhoto gotamassa yugaṃ vā naṅgalaṃ vā phālaṃ vā pācanaṃ vā balībadde vā.
snp1.4:3.2.eng: “I don’t see the worthy Gotama with a yoke or plow or plowshare or goad or oxen, yet he says:

snp1.4:3.3.pli: Atha ca pana bhavaṃ gotamo evamāha:

snp1.4:3.4.pli: ‘ahampi kho, brāhmaṇa, kasāmi ca vapāmi ca; kasitvā ca vapitvā ca bhuñjāmī’”ti.
snp1.4:3.4.eng: ‘I too plough and sow, brahmin, and then I eat.’”

snp1.4:4.1.pli: Atha kho kasibhāradvājo brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:
snp1.4:4.1.eng: Then Bhāradvāja the Farmer addressed the Buddha in verse:

snp1.4:5.2.eng: but I don’t see you farming.

snp1.4:5.3.eng: Tell me your farming when asked,

snp1.4:5.4.eng: so I can recognize your farming.”

snp1.4:6.1.eng: “Faith is my seed, fervor my rain,

snp1.4:6.2.eng: and wisdom is my yoke and plough.

snp1.4:6.3.eng: Conscience is my pole, mind my strap,

snp1.4:7.2.eng: I restrict my intake of food.

snp1.4:7.3.eng: I use truth as my scythe,

snp1.4:8.1.eng: Energy is my beast of burden,

snp1.4:8.2.eng: transporting me to sanctuary from the yoke.

snp1.4:9.1.eng: That’s how to do the farming

snp1.4:9.2.eng: that has freedom from death as its fruit.

snp1.4:10.1.pli: Atha kho kasibhāradvājo brāhmaṇo mahatiyā kaṃsapātiyā pāyasaṃ vaḍḍhetvā bhagavato upanāmesi:
snp1.4:10.1.eng: Then Bhāradvāja the Farmer poured milk-rice in a large bronze cup and presented it to the Buddha:

snp1.4:10.2.eng: “May the worthy Gotama eat the milk-rice!

snp1.4:10.3.eng: The worthy one is a farmer.

snp1.4:10.4.pli: yañhi bhavaṃ gotamo amatapphalaṃ kasiṃ kasatī”ti.
snp1.4:10.4.eng: For the worthy Gotama does the farming that has freedom from death as its fruit.”

snp1.4:11.1.eng: “Food enchanted by a verse isn’t fit for me to eat.

snp1.4:11.2.eng: That’s not the principle of those who see, brahmin.

snp1.4:11.3.eng: The Buddhas cast aside things enchanted with verses.

snp1.4:11.4.eng: Since there is such a principle, brahmin, <j>that’s how they live.

snp1.4:12.1.eng: Serve with other food and drink

snp1.4:12.2.eng: the consummate one, the great seer,

snp1.4:12.3.eng: with defilements ended and remorse stilled.

snp1.4:12.4.eng: For he is the field for the seeker of merit.”

snp1.4:13.1.pli: “Atha kassa cāhaṃ, bho gotama, imaṃ pāyasaṃ dammī”ti?
snp1.4:13.1.eng: “Then, worthy Gotama, to whom should I give the milk-rice?”

snp1.4:13.2.pli: “Na khvāhaṃ taṃ, brāhmaṇa, passāmi sadevake loke samārake sabrahmake sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiyā pajāya sadevamanussāya, yassa so pāyaso bhutto sammā pariṇāmaṃ gaccheyya, aññatra tathāgatassa vā tathāgatasāvakassa vā.
snp1.4:13.2.eng: “Brahmin, I don’t see anyone in this world—with its gods, Māras, and Divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans—who can properly digest this milk-rice, except for the Realized One or one of his disciples.

snp1.4:13.3.pli: Tena hi tvaṃ, brāhmaṇa, taṃ pāyasaṃ appaharite vā chaḍḍehi appāṇake vā udake opilāpehī”ti.
snp1.4:13.3.eng: Well then, brahmin, throw out the milk-rice where there is little that grows, or drop it into water that has no living creatures.”

snp1.4:14.1.pli: Atha kho kasibhāradvājo brāhmaṇo taṃ pāyasaṃ appāṇake udake opilāpesi.
snp1.4:14.1.eng: So Bhāradvāja the Farmer dropped the milk-rice in water that had no living creatures.

snp1.4:14.2.pli: Atha kho so pāyaso udake pakkhitto cicciṭāyati ciṭiciṭāyati sandhūpāyati sampadhūpāyati.
snp1.4:14.2.eng: And when the milk-rice was placed in the water, it sizzled and hissed, steaming and fuming.

snp1.4:14.3.pli: Seyyathāpi nāma phālo divasaṃ santatto udake pakkhitto cicciṭāyati ciṭiciṭāyati sandhūpāyati sampadhūpāyati;
snp1.4:14.3.eng: Suppose there was an iron cauldron that had been heated all day. If you placed it in the water, it would sizzle and hiss, steaming and fuming.

snp1.4:14.4.pli: evamevaṃ so pāyaso udake pakkhitto cicciṭāyati ciṭiciṭāyati sandhūpāyati sampadhūpāyati.
snp1.4:14.4.eng: In the same way, when the milk-rice was placed in the water, it sizzled and hissed, steaming and fuming.

snp1.4:15.1.pli: Atha kho kasibhāradvājo brāhmaṇo saṃviggo lomahaṭṭhajāto yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavato pādesu sirasā nipatitvā bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
snp1.4:15.1.eng: Then Bhāradvāja the Farmer, shocked and awestruck,  went up to the Buddha, bowed down with his head at the Buddha’s feet, and said,

snp1.4:15.3.pli: Seyyathāpi, bho gotama, nikkujjitaṃ vā ukkujjeyya, paṭicchannaṃ vā vivareyya, mūḷhassa vā maggaṃ ācikkheyya, andhakāre vā telapajjotaṃ dhāreyya, ‘cakkhumanto rūpāni dakkhantī’ti; evamevaṃ bhotā gotamena anekapariyāyena dhammo pakāsito.
snp1.4:15.3.eng: As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with clear eyes can see what’s there, worthy Gotama has made the teaching clear in many ways.

snp1.4:15.4.pli: Esāhaṃ bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ saraṇaṃ gacchāmi dhammañca bhikkhusaṅghañca,
snp1.4:15.4.eng: I go for refuge to the worthy Gotama, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.

snp1.4:15.5.pli: labheyyāhaṃ bhoto gotamassa santike pabbajjaṃ, labheyyaṃ upasampadan”ti.
snp1.4:15.5.eng: May I receive the going forth, the ordination in the worthy Gotama’s presence?”

snp1.4:16.1.pli: Alattha kho kasibhāradvājo brāhmaṇo bhagavato santike pabbajjaṃ, alattha upasampadaṃ.
snp1.4:16.1.eng: And Bhāradvāja the Farmer received the going forth, the ordination in the Buddha’s presence.

snp1.4:16.2.pli: Acirūpasampanno kho panāyasmā bhāradvājo eko vūpakaṭṭho appamatto ātāpī pahitatto viharanto nacirasseva—yassatthāya kulaputtā sammadeva agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajanti, tadanuttaraṃ—brahmacariyapariyosānaṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja vihāsi.
snp1.4:16.2.eng: Not long after his ordination, Venerable Bhāradvāja, living alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute, soon realized the supreme end of the spiritual path in this very life. He lived having achieved with his own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.

snp1.4:16.3.pli: “Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā”ti abbhaññāsi.
snp1.4:16.3.eng: He understood: “Rebirth is ended; the spiritual journey has been completed; what had to be done has been done; there is nothing further for this place.”

snp1.4:16.4.pli: Aññataro ca panāyasmā bhāradvājo arahataṃ ahosīti.
snp1.4:16.4.eng: And Venerable Bhāradvāja became one of the perfected.

snp1.5:1.1.eng: “I ask the sage abounding in wisdom,”

snp1.5:1.3.eng: “the Buddha, master of the teaching, free of craving,

snp1.5:1.4.eng: best of men, excellent charioteer, please tell me this:

snp1.5:1.5.eng: how many ascetics are there in the world?”

snp1.5:2.1.eng: “There are four ascetics, not a fifth.”

snp1.5:2.3.eng: “Being asked to bear witness, <j>I will explain them to you:
snp1.5:2.3.comm: Sakkhipuṭṭho is only elsewhere used in the context of being asked to bear witness in court. I think the context is relevant here, as the Buddha is offering personal testimony on “judging” others.

snp1.5:3.1.eng: “Who is a path-victor according to the Buddhas?”

snp1.5:3.3.eng: “and how is one an unequaled explainer of the path?

snp1.5:3.4.eng: Tell me when asked about one who lives the path,

snp1.5:4.3.eng: a guide for the world with its gods.

snp1.5:4.4.eng: The Buddhas say one such is victor of the path.

snp1.5:5.2.eng: they explain and analyze the teaching right here.

snp1.5:5.3.eng: That sage unstirred, with doubt cut off,

snp1.5:5.4.eng: is the second mendicant, I say, the teacher of the path.

snp1.5:6.1.eng: Living restrained and mindful on the path

snp1.5:6.2.eng: of the well-taught passage of teaching,
snp1.5:6.2.comm: Norman and Bodhi both read pada as “way”, but it surely means “passage” as eg. AN 4.191:1.7.

snp1.5:6.4.eng: is the third mendicant, I say, the path-liver.

snp1.5:7.1.eng: Dressed like one true to their vows,

snp1.5:7.2.eng: pushy, rude, a corrupter of families,

snp1.5:7.4.eng: the path-wrecker’s life is a sham.

snp1.5:8.3.eng: knows that ‘They are not all like that one’.

snp1.5:8.4.pli: Iti disvā na hāpeti tassa saddhā;
snp1.5:8.4.eng: So when they see them they don’t lose their faith.

snp1.5:8.5.eng: For how could one equate them—

snp1.5:8.6.eng: the corrupt with the uncorrupt, <j>the pure with the impure?”

snp1.6:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
snp1.6:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

snp1.6:1.3.pli: Atha kho aññatarā devatā abhikkantāya rattiyā abhikkantavaṇṇā kevalakappaṃ jetavanaṃ obhāsetvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi.
snp1.6:1.3.eng: Then, late at night, a glorious deity, lighting up the entire Jeta’s Grove, went up to the Buddha, bowed, and stood to one side.

snp1.6:1.4.pli: Ekamantaṃ ṭhitā kho sā devatā bhagavantaṃ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:
snp1.6:1.4.eng: Standing to one side, that deity addressed the Buddha in verse:

snp1.6:2.1.comm: Several of the examples are gendered so I use “man”.

snp1.6:2.3.eng: We have come to ask you, sir:
snp1.6:2.3.comm: Accept variant bhavantaṁ in this and similar passages. Bhagavantaṁ is hypermetrical.

snp1.6:3.1.comm: For “easy to understand” (suvijāna) cf. Rig Veda 7.104.12 and durvijñāna at Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 11.5.5.13.

snp1.6:3.2.eng: understanding downfall is just as easy.

snp1.6:3.3.eng: One who loves the teaching succeeds,
snp1.6:3.3.comm: Dhammakāmo is apparently always used in this sense.

snp1.6:3.4.eng: but a hater of the teaching meets their downfall.”

snp1.6:4.3.eng: Tell us the second, Blessed One:

snp1.6:5.2.eng: he has no love for the good.

snp1.6:5.3.eng: He believes the teaching of the bad;

snp1.6:5.4.eng: and that leads to his downfall.”

snp1.6:6.3.eng: Tell us the third, Blessed One:

snp1.6:7.2.eng: a man who does no work;

snp1.6:7.4.eng: and that leads to his downfall.”

snp1.6:8.3.eng: Tell us the fourth, Blessed One:

snp1.6:9.1.eng: “Though able, he does not look after

snp1.6:9.4.eng: and that leads to his downfall.”

snp1.6:10.3.eng: Tell us the fifth, Blessed One:

snp1.6:11.4.eng: and that leads to his downfall.”

snp1.6:12.3.eng: Tell us the sixth, Blessed One:

snp1.6:13.4.eng: and that leads to his downfall.”

snp1.6:14.3.eng: Tell us the seventh, Blessed One:

snp1.6:15.3.eng: looks down on his own family,

snp1.6:15.4.eng: and that leads to his downfall.”

snp1.6:16.3.eng: Tell us the eighth, Blessed One:

snp1.6:17.3.eng: wastes all that he has earned,

snp1.6:17.4.eng: and that leads to his downfall.”

snp1.6:18.3.eng: Tell us the ninth, Blessed One:

snp1.6:19.2.comm: Both Norman and Bodhi read dissati, I read dussati. The Buddha, after all, was “seen” with prostitutes.

snp1.6:19.4.eng: and that leads to his downfall.”

snp1.6:20.3.eng: Tell us the tenth, Blessed One:

snp1.6:21.2.eng: marries a girl with budding breasts;

snp1.6:21.4.eng: and that leads to his downfall.”

snp1.6:22.3.eng: Tell us the eleventh, Blessed One:

snp1.6:23.3.eng: who’s a drunkard and a wastrel,

snp1.6:23.4.eng: and that leads to his downfall.”

snp1.6:24.3.eng: Tell us the twelfth, Blessed One:

snp1.6:25.1.eng: “A man of little wealth and strong craving,

snp1.6:25.4.eng: and that leads to his downfall.

snp1.6:26.1.eng: Seeing these downfalls in the world,

snp1.6:26.4.eng: will enjoy a world of grace.”
